objectives: Sign core weather/season vocabulary and place descriptions in space
Use time-first framing (TODAY/TOMORROW/RECENT) to report weather
Ask/answer HOW-WEATHER?/TEMPERATURE? with correct NMMs and compact clauses

vocab.def: General weather sign; WH-face for questions about conditions.
High-frequency conditions signed in front of torso.
Question about numeric temp; pair with numbers.
Lead sentences with TODAY/TOMORROW/RECENT for clarity.

sections.heading: Warm-Up: Season Strip

media.caption: Cycle seasons slowly with neutral wrist

sections.body: Mirror **SPRING, SUMMER, FALL, WINTER**. Keep motions compact; add matching face (e.g., **WINTER** ‚Üí slight **COLD** face).

microCheck.q: To make WINTER feel colder you primarily adjust‚Ä¶

sections.heading: Model: Weather Conditions + Time-First
sections.body:
Use **TIME ‚Üí CONDITION ‚Üí (TEMP/PLACE)**. Examples:
‚Ä¢ **TODAY RAIN COOL.**
‚Ä¢ **TOMORROW SUNNY WARM.**
‚Ä¢ **RECENT WIND STRONG.** Keep clauses compact with small pauses.

sections.heading: Questions: HOW-WEATHER? & TEMPERATURE?
sections.body: **HOW-WEATHER?** (WH-face). **TEMPERATURE?** (WH-face) ‚Üí answer with number + **DEGREE** and adjective: **70 DEGREE WARM.**
sections.teacherNote: Coach tiny pauses between condition and temperature.

sections.heading: Partner Practice: Two-City Report
sections.body: Anchor **CITY-A** on left and **CITY-B** on right. A reports **TODAY CITY-A RAIN COOL 58. CITY-B SUNNY WARM 75.** B asks **TEMPERATURE?** or **HOW-WEATHER?**; switch roles.

callouts.title: Space Consistency
callouts.body: Point to the same space for each city every time.

sections.heading: Mini-Showcase
sections.body: Record **10‚Äì15s**: **TODAY** weather + **TOMORROW** forecast (condition + temp word or degree). Example: **TODAY CLOUDY COOL. TOMORROW RAIN COLD.**
sections.teacherNote: Privacy submissions OK; caption should state if you used degree numbers or adjectives.

options: Reusing the same points for places

items.q: Write an ASL gloss: TODAY WIND STRONG. TOMORROW SUNNY WARM.

items.prompt: What helped your clarity more: time-first or space anchoring? What will you practice next?

summary: You led with time, used compact weather clauses, and anchored places consistently for clear reports.
